neutron/tests/fullstack/base.py.message: nit: IMO, this note is not needed. In fullstack tests, the subnets are created using a CIDR (--subnet-range). This CIDR will generate an allocation pool. We'll always have at least one allocation pool.
Personally I feel it is better to add notes, to make the code readers life easier.

This operation is very inefficient. Instead of this, you should use IPRange:

ipr = netaddr.IPRange(valid_ip_pool['start'], valid_ip_pool['end'])
valid_ips = netaddr.IPSet(ipr)

As an example, with /8 networks:
ip1='10.0.0.1'
ip2='10.255.255.254'
ipr_a = netaddr.iter_iprange(ip1, ip2)
ipr_b = netaddr.IPRange(ip1, ip2)
ips_a = netaddr.IPSet(ipr_a)  # 104 seconds in my laptop
ips_b = netaddr.IPSet(ipr_b)  # 0.0004 seconds, same result.
Thanks Rodolfo, iter_iprange is really worse than IPRange, good catch

b) Linklayer: currently is not possible to define the linklayer in the TC filter using pyroute2. nova/network/security_group/neutron_driv.message:
Yeah the stuff used in here might not be in the fields list of returned keys for security groups. So we have a few options I think:

1. detailed=True and fields are mutually exclusive, specifying both is an error

2. detailed=True overrides any fields specified

3. detailed=True means we add everything needed in this method to fields if not specified

--

Option 1 is gross since callers would have to handle the error.

Option 3 tightly couples to what's used in this method.

Option 2 is likely the best since if you ask for detailed=True you shouldn't be using fields to narrow the results.
nit: could just drop this so you don't accidentally set fields to [] if something passed an empty list.

OK this is why you need 'id' in the fields list. We could just always hard-code fields in here to be something like:

sg_fields = ['id']
if fields:
  sg_fields.extend(fields)
  sg_fields = list(set(sg_fields))  # remove duplicates

But that's a nit. It's also something you'd want to do outside the for loop.

Actually I guess there is a bug in what I proposed. If we always request at a minimum fields=['id'] then anything that was calling this expecting the full response will be broken.

So it's more likely better to only request fields if specified and ensure id is in the set so the caller doesn't have to worry about passing id if they don't use it.
Which way do you prefer?  As long as we don't ask for the rules and hit its JOIN, the other fields are all fast.
That sounds quite good, I'll change it that way. Thanks.

I was mostly (but not super) concerned about the metadata API code needing to pass 'id' in the fields when it's not using the id, so it's tightly coupled to the inner workings of this method. So I'd prefer that this code is smart enough to always request id and treat the incoming fields as additional but id will always be returned. So the metadata API code could just cleanly ask for 'name' and that's all it cares about.
So looking at this, if detailed is True, we call _convert_to_nova_security_group_format which is going to want more fields than what might be in the fields list.

This is a bit tricky if detailed=True and fields is not None...

(later)

The more I worked on this locally, and tried to deal with detailed and fields both being specified, the more I realized that 'name' has to also be specified in fields because of how get_instances_security_groups_bindings works in the non-detailed case.

So at a minimum if detailed=False, fields should contain 'id' and 'name', and if we're going to do that, we might as well just drop the fields kwarg and say if detailed is False, just hard-code fields to be ['id', 'name'] since we won't use anything else. That makes this a much simpler fix and restricts it to just this module.
Note to self: here's the convert method call.

releasenotes/notes/allocation_conflict_r.message:
Does this "busy clustered hypervisor" mean a big single resource provider? I thought VMware (and Ironic) had only one nova-compute service for N compute-nodes but had N resource providers for N compute nodes.

That said, I still don't get why decrease of the clients - nova-compute, the alloc reporters - causes concurrency on one resource provider.

> In a vsphere setup, there is one resource provider for a cluster

Okay, that makes sense and clear things.

 > It's true that in ironic there are many resource providers
 > associated with the one nova-compute process, but this is not the
 > case when using the vmware virt driver.

Yes, this was my question. Then why is ironic case mentioned in the release note? Theoritically, the same situation does not happen on ironic where nodes are not combined to a single resource provider, does it? 

 > [1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/010669.html

Agreed that this ML discussion [1] is related both to ironic case and to VMware case, because the root cause of this is to have one nova-compute to report all nodes with a lock on client side. But the root cause of story/2006467 seems to be having a big resource provider with big inventory on server side, which sounds to me a bit different with the lock discussion above and not relevant to ironic, I think?

In a vsphere setup, there is one resource provider for a cluster which could have a very big inventory (1000s of vcpus in some rare cases). In such a setup there is only one nova-compute in the entire openstack installation.

That means that when there is a request to schedule a workload, it will get one allocation candidate in response, and try to write allocations for it. If nova-scheduler is running currently (which it now does by default) several of these allocations can happen at once, to the same resource provider and each successful one will bump the resource provider generation, increasing the chance of conflict for the others.

It's true that in ironic there are many resource providers associated with the one nova-compute process, but this is not the case when using the vmware virt driver. In that setup, all the individual physical hosts in the cluster are considered as one big one.

This was a design decision made sometime in the past to allow vmware features like DRS (distributed resource scheduler), vMotion (unattended automatic live migration), and other features (High Availability, Fault Tolerance, Admission Control) to work in the fancy way that vmware wants them to.

It's been acknowledged time and again that this causes an impedance mismatch with how nova wants to think about hypervisors (see [1] for a recent discussion) but efforts to do things differently have foundered and floundered.


[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/010669.html

> 
 > Yes, this was my question. Then why is ironic case mentioned in the
 > release note? Theoritically, the same situation does not happen on
 > ironic where nodes are not combined to a single resource provider,
 > does it?
 
Good point, I'll make the note more specific.
It looks like you made the note more general :P

Ultimately it shouldn't be a super common warning either way, and the text already suggests that. In fact it should probably be debug, tbh, but I'd prefer to leave that discussion for another patch.
nit, could fold 'backing' into the main message

This should be unreachable since you're explicitly only trapping the two exceptions from the prior conditions. Did you mean to just trap Exception on L9579? Or are you future-proofing against someone adding to the except list but forgetting to add a condition here?

The lists are duplicated because I couldn't think of a good way to do this without a duplicated list. This isn't a problem in strongly typed languages where omitting a case in the second list can normally be turned into a compilation error, but unfortunately python requires us to either trust people not to make mistakes, or implement these features ourselves.

The NameError works too, though, as long as nobody refactors this at some point in the future to define thing outside the if else block, not realising that it's a safety feature. I could add a comment, I guess, but that wouldn't be automatic and would be no shorter than the assertion it replaces. I thought the assertion was more explicit, and explicit > implicit (https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0020/#id3).

Compared to the bug it fixes, though, this is utterly inconsequential. I'll remove it for an easy life ;)

The latter, hence it's an assertion. Duplicated lists which are required to be identical make me nervous :)

Incidentally, there must be something cleaner than assert False for this? Meh, this is fine.

> Duplicated lists which are
 > required to be identical make me nervous :)

But that's... basically what you've done.

I'm not objecting to that per se (see below); I just think this looks weird and isn't necessary.

...because all you actually have to do to enforce it is remove these three lines, and L9593 will explode with an uninitialized 'thing'.

swift/common/wsgi.py.message: The listening sockets should be gracefully shutdown before execv() is called. Otherwise, the parent is accepting connections right before killing itself to exec the new binary.

The parent never calls accept() on the listen sockets, so this is not an issue.  In fact, closing the sockets instead of letting close-on-exec close them introduced a (very slim) window of client connection error.  So this should definitely be left as it is in the patch and not changed.
Oh, right, of course!  The old listen sockets should be closed in the parent prior to the exec, and then I can cut out the `set_close_on_exec_on_listen_sockets()` stuff too!
I'm wondering how we can avoid downtime if the new process does not start (eg: config mistake). I don't know yet how we could do. Right now it just exits and the service is down.
That's no different than the old SIGHUP case and dealing with that is out of scope for this code.

Being here means the execv() failed. Would it raise an exception? In either cases, I prefer the process to continue running than to quit. Just need to find a proper way to notify the operator that the reload failed.

If the exec failed, something is _seriously_ wrong and continuing to run will almost certainly cause more trouble than exiting.

The operator already has to be able to deal with the server not being up (consider old SIGHUP "reload" case with a bad new config).  So this is no new burden.  If we can't exec, we probably can't continue to do anything safe or good by continuing to run.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I agree. We can think about such improvement separately.

It's used in the api to filter out those migrations:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/migrations.py#L56

We could set hidden=True for the older migration, but I'm not sure it would simplify the code any. When looking through the code trying to simplify what you have here, it's unfortunate to see how many times we iterate the migration list from the lister through to the API. The api uses an obj_to_primitive() but for no reason, which eliminates the ability to return a generator. Moving the filtering logic to the api would remove the extra loop you're adding, which is tempting, but...

> It's used in the api to filter out those migrations:
 > 
 > https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/migrations.py#L56
 > 

I mean it's never set to True so that filter is kind of useless today. The API reference also mentions that:

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=list-migrations-detail#list-migrations

"But the ‘hidden’ setting of migration is always 0, so this parameter is useless to filter migrations."

> The api uses an obj_to_primitive() but for no reason, which eliminates the ability to return a generator.

That is just dumb code in the route handler and could be fixed separately. What we normally have in a route handler like this is a ViewBuilder implementation which will explicitly pull the fields off the object that go into the response, not what we have here where we convert to dicts and then delete fields which is backward.

> > I mean it's never set to True so that filter is kind of useless
 > > today.
 > 
 > Sure, but I thought you were saying setting the hidden bit in your
 > loop wouldn't get honored.
 > 

Ack, I think I misunderstood your point.

So we could set migration.hidden=True/False through the cross-cell resize operation and just let the API always filter out the hidden=False ones like it does today. But unlike the instance being marked hidden or not during the resize and until after the user confirms/reverts it, we copy all of the instance migrations to the target cell DB early:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/7aa88029bbf6311033457c32801963da01e88ecb/nova/conductor/tasks/cross_cell_migrate.py#L189

That's because once we update the instance mapping to point at the target cell, that's where the API will go to list migrations for the instance, so we'll have more duplicates than just the "active" migration for the resize operation. To make sure those duplicates are filtered out of the GET /os-migrations API we'd have to also set those to hidden=True/False depending on where we are in the operation, i.e. they are hidden in the target DB until the resize is done and we expose the target cell instance.

> I mean it's never set to True so that filter is kind of useless
 > today.

Sure, but I thought you were saying setting the hidden bit in your loop wouldn't get honored.

 > That is just dumb code in the route handler and could be fixed
 > separately. What we normally have in a route handler like this is a
 > ViewBuilder implementation which will explicitly pull the fields
 > off the object that go into the response, not what we have here
 > where we convert to dicts and then delete fields which is backward.

Yeah, so if we were to fix that we could make your new loop return a generator to do the filtering inline and collapse a lot of the repetition. However, I know, it's not a big deal, this stuff just builds up over time to get us a super inefficient overall system.

nova/compute/api.py.message: migration.hidden would not solve this either as we don't know which migration was active at which time window. So I guess we cannot really support changes-before filters here.
Maybe I should just remove this FIXME comment. _get_unique_filter_method has the same issue.
old and new is double loaded here as it talks about time. first_updated_at , second_updated_at feels bad too. Maybe already_found_updated_at, newly_found_update_at would be better but that is long.
How about mapped_updated_at and incoming_updated_at or something like that?
Don't we have to compare doppleganger.created_at with migration.update_at here?

I suppose you could also have a case where doppleganger.updated_at is not None but migration.updated_at is None and migration.created_at > doppleganger.updated_at.

I should probably re-write this logic into a simple function to just return the newer of two objects and always update the dict.

Meaning if doppleganger.updated_at is None but doppleganger.created_at is > migration.updated_at, we don't overwrite doppleganger in the dict because it's technically newer, right? I'll add a test and condition for it.
If you don't want to use ddt and just implement the suggested reversed, this is the only case you're missing.
Done
You haven't got complete unit test coverage here. Suggest ddt would be a simple way to go.
https://pastebin.com/pHtM7iEf

> Can't you replace all of this with:
 > 
 > if (updated_at1, created_at1) < (updated_at2, created_at2):
 > return obj1
 > else:
 > return obj2
 > 
 > ?

As discussed, this doesn't handle updated_at being None, but you fixed that in your paste below.

And the logic above is wrong since the function is supposed to return the newer object so the < should be > or swap the objects being returned. That's an easy fix.

But the bigger issue is test_get_migrations_sorted_filter_duplicates_using_created_at fails with this and it's not the same as the logic I have, which says that if an object has a newer created_at than the other object's updated_at, we take the object with the newer created_at. Your paste with handling None is not handling that properly.

Unless there is a simple way to make that work with the tuples, I think it's likely not worth the complexity/readability since what I have here is explicit.

Per the comment, updated_at might be None and you can't compare datetime objects to None:

>>> now1 = datetime.datetime.now()
>>> now2 = datetime.datetime.now()
>>> now1 < now2
True
>>> now1 < None
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: can't compare datetime.datetime to NoneType

As noted earlier in discussion, during a cross cell migration we copy the existing migration records from the source cell to the target cell db so we'd maybe have to mark more than just the 'current' migration as hidden, i.e. all of the existing ones too while they are in the target cell db before we flip the instance mapping to point at the target cell. Doing that would be kind of nasty.

The one saving thing there would be any existing completed migrations that get copied are likely really just duplicates, so their created_at/updated_at values aren't going to change since they are old and done, so for those we could likely just do a simple duplication filter by uuid (like _get_unique_filter_method for instances). If that worked, then it would really be only the 'active' migration that needs the hidden flag management and we can filter that thing out in the DB API like we do for the hidden instance.

BTW, I'm OK with people deleting allocations and then using heal_allocations, and I've recommended that in IRC before when people were struggling with a bunch of migration-based allocations for failed migrations for a specific instance and we (nova) weren't cleaning up the allocations properly. It's also why I added the --instance option to heal_allocations so people can target just a specific problem instance rather than process everything. The examples above are still useful as an exercise to show how those commands are used and how things link together between nova and placement for allocation tracking.
Mel pointed out in IRC that heal_allocations was added in Rocky so that's another reason to go into the details above in case you're a lonely soul on RHOSP's LTS release (based on Queens).

Yeah, a couple of other reasons would be:

- heal_allocations won't deal with migration records so if you deleted allocations for pending migration-based allocations it'll be lost

- heal_allocations may not work with nested allocations before Train, e.g. servers with QoS ports attached

nit: range
Done

In the discussion at the PTG, one option that was discussed for this was to look at the capabilities of oslo.config to handle triaging between config files (which it handles already) and a database.  It turns out that oslo.config does have the capability to have custom backend drivers that could be used to implement such functionality [1].  I brought this up in the oslo team meeting [2] and one drawback for an oslo config driver was noted: re-reading the config from database would probably require sending the process a SIGHUP signal at least.  The advice was to go with a more natural data model, and make as part of the upgrade path something that would prepopulate the table with the contents of the config if the config was preexisting.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/oslo-specs/specs/queens/oslo-config-drivers.html
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/oslo/2018/oslo.2018-09-17-15.01.log.html#l-91

Also it seems to me that while --minimum and --maximum are atomically optional, a user would need to supply one o the other.  With neither, it seems like no action would be taken.

specs/stein/scalable-ovs-agent.rst.message: Rather than a simple hash algorithm, there may need to be additional logic to map OVSes to super agents.  In the edge use case, neutron may control multiple edge regions and a super agent may need to handle all of the OVSes in one of those edge regions.  In that case we would need to ensure that hashing was geographically based rather than a basic hash map.

I just took a stab at rephrasing this paragraph to increase clarity. This is what I came up with:

Another use case is one where cloud user A launches 2 VMs in different subnets,
which are connected with a router (there may be other subnets linked to the 
same router). One of the VMs, X, is used by A's customers. The other VM ,Y, is
the access point to a ``private environment`` that performs additional processing
to some of the traffic generated by the users in VM X that may include VPN,
firewall, QoS. Traffic from VM X directed inside the OpenStack will be
processed normally by the router. Other traffic from VM X, which is directed
to the outside, has to pass through the ``private environment`` before 
accessing the internet. The ``private environment`` must not be exposed to the 
customer, so user A doesn't allow the route table of VM X to contain
any special routes. As a consequence, the router has to discriminate such traffic
based on a combination of its source subnet and its destination. 
The traffic from each subnet which is attached to this router may need

For me it sounds like use case for metering on Neutron side and Heat to orchestrate it and manage alarms

We could consider that the congestion is new network metric. We think that the congestion is a network QoS related issue and could be managed by Neutron entirely, where we use bandwidth limit policies to react to the congestion and keep good network performance. But using Heat is a possibility indeed, where Neutron only feeds metrics that another system can use to react. What we propose is a Neutron-only solution that we would like to discuss to see if it can fit the Neutron prerogatives.

currently bandwidth limit are classless so AFAIU You will want to limit traffic to other VMs in same network but You will limit whole traffic from VM, also e.g. traffic which will be send through L3 router to the Internet.

You're right, there is no possibility to limit the traffic to other VMs from the traffic to the Internet. The logic behind limiting a congestion inducing VM is that it would not disturb the traffic of other VMs, so whether the traffic from the VM is to its network or to the Internet, we consider it as impacting the rest of the traffic.
can't You associate it with exiting QoS bandwidth limit rule here instead of repeat its parameters?
It's a good idea, we could associate it with existing bandwidth limit rule and avoid adding two new variables.

I'm not sure, You want to add some periodic notifications, calculations of congestion packets bandwidth and dynamically changed QoS rules for (maybe) many ports. Will it be without any impact on performance?

You're right, but the question is more related to the configuration rather than the process itself. For example, if we are limited on resources we could increase the notification time to collect marked packets, which means that the controller will not be solicited as before. Moreover, if we configure a low value of min-cong-kbps the controller will not quickly release the policed VMs, so the network stats will be stable longer than if the min-cong-kbps is near to max-cong-kbps. The latter case, the controller will quickly released and policed VMs, which adds an overhead to the network. For the congestion calculation phase, we could optimize it by using multiple NIO (Non blocking I/O) thread. Which is more optimized technique than simple IO multiple thread. Finally, we think that the treatment of network congestion is an important task that will for sure increase the network performance, so perhaps improving physical resources for monitoring and management process is a good idea.

With my deployer/operator hat on, I'm not sure we would want to automatically re-balance things automatically.  For example, when operators decide to make changes to customer "equipment" (assume a neutron router is equipment), they have to schedule a service window, notify the cusomer(s), make the change and verify things are operating correctly - if not a rollback might be attempted.

While moving a dhcp server might not cause any noticable impact, moving a router could (even a 10-second drop of packets would be noticed), triggering other failovers or SLA complications.  For that reason I think any re-balancing that lives in neutron should be triggered via an API call that an admin can make.  I know this looks like the script method mentioned above, but being inside the server should make it faster and less error-prone (i think).

might be better than "reschedule everything if necessary", since we want to do the least amount of work to impact the least amount of tenants.

Lets discuss this more. I think we can move fwd to a solution.

@Sridar,

I just came back from the Berlin Summit and managed to get back to your comment.

First, let me rephrase what your comment and make sure I correctly understand what your mean. Currently, the mapping between firewall groups and firewall policies (ingress/egress) is one-to-one. Your suggestion is to turn it into a one-to-many mapping. Is that correct?

From my side, the real requirement is a more flexible and comprehensive model that allows us to address different use cases from enterprise. By analyzing the existing use cases and potential future use cases, I think it is a quite intuitive and reasonable to have multiple FWGs applied on a single port. The alternative approach you suggested (multiple firewall policies on a single FWG) might address some of the problems but doesn't seem to be enough.

I tried to summarize the requirements as below:

1. Encapsulation of business logic. In production, it is quite common to have one FWG defined for one business logic. For example, we could have one FWG defined for web, another FWG defined for windows, and yet another FWG defined for quarantined application. As a result, if there is a VM that hosts a web server with windows operating system. We can apply both "web" and "windows" FWGs to this VM. Later, if we detect the VM is compromised, we can add "quarantined" FWG as well. After the problem is resolved, we remove the "quarantined" FWG and the VM is restored as it was.

2. Dynamic firewall rule. The use case is described in another spec [1]. As a summary, we want to have the ability to add/remove FWG at runtime. The multiple FWGs per neutron port model allows us to apply "static" FWG to port on creation, and apply "dynamic" FWG to port at runtime. An example is (again) the compromised VM example. We want to let the VM to be created with "web" FWG and add/remove "quarantined" FWG at the runtime.

Based on above requirements, this spec proposes to add support for multiple FWGs per port. The introduction of "priority" attribute is simply for resolving the potential conflicting between FWGs on the same port. I am really open for suggestions if there are better alternative.

To the bottom, I think the support of multiple FWGs per port is critical because the lack of this support might block a bunch of use cases and it cannot be easily work-around. However, if you have a better alternative, we can discuss it further.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/597724/
I am still wondering if we want to bring this in the notion of priority and associate it with a Policy in a FWG
I was thinking more to use roles defined in OpenStack rather than create a new Resource in the context of FWaaS.

how is this different from the existing method to exclude ports where network security is disabled?

The excluded port feature proposed in here is scoped within a firewall group. The disabling of network security is not scoped by any firewall group.

For example, if we exclude a port from a firewall group. The port is not touched by this firewall group but other associated firewall groups or default firewall group will still apply. However, disabling network security for this port seems to have the effect of excluding all firewall groups.

I don't believe this has ever been a realistic concern. Any failure which would cause this would also, in practice, cause the failure of the application in any case.

Additionally, the failure windows also tends to be very short in practise.

1. Live migration without the above also involves a short pause.

2. Auto-converge won't be used unless live migration is failing. Post-copy will also be very, very short unless live migration is failing. IOW, this spec amounts to: disable live migration for certain guests.

Given that live migration is an admin action, if the cloud operator doesn't want to live migrate a guest, what's stopping them from just not live migrating the guest?

cyborg/api/hooks.py.message:
PS3 was failing, while PS6 is working. The changes [1] seem like black magic to me, TBH. We should get further review of this part.


[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/685542/3..6/cyborg/api/hooks.py

I agree this could use review by experts... but I'm not sure there are many of those left.

I think part of what's going on here has to do with the fact that, when not using api_servers, we're going to the service catalog and/or keystoneauth1 to look up endpoints. And glance (like nova, until [1] lands) incorrectly requires authentication to access the version document under /v2, which is ultimately where that endpoint comes from. And until [2] (which recently merged and was released in 3.18.0, so you could depend on it and maybe simplify some of the stuff below) ksa only tried to do version discovery unauthenticated. That could have caused the guts of get_{ksa|sdk}_adapter to blow up.

So what this might be doing is overriding the service catalog so the discovery doesn't have to go all the way to the glance API.

The auth plugin initialization looks like it might have simply been modernized to exploit functionality that's been consolidated into keystonemiddleware. I'm not sure if there's a functional difference; perhaps a keystoner would be able to chime in there.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/685181/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/685042/

nova/compute/resource_tracker.py.message: This is also stale from a refactor where this comment was moving from _update() into this method. I'll fix in a FUP as well.
could stand to drop this as well

OK so the comment was added in this change:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/518294/

Back in Queens when the xenapi driver was implementing support for VGPUs and the driver didn't implement update_provider_tree (that was added here Ie7bc0b3d3c3d5b1cdea124f6415aa0e87ac8b757 in Train) but did implement get_inventory:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e2a18a37190e4c7b7697a8811553d331e208182c/nova/virt/xenapi/driver.py#L407

Note that the xenapi driver didn't yet report VGPU inventory yet.

So looking at that change:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/518294/2/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py

The point was that the code before would short-circuit if fields on the compute node didn't change:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/518294/2/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py@a808

Which meant we couldn't call the driver's get_inventory method and update placement, which would be wrong if the driver's VGPU inventory changed (which isn't tracked on the ComputeNode object).

I guess the NOTE was added based on this comment:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/518294/1/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py@795

Saying effectively if the provider tree says inventory has changed (for the most part that's just going to be VCPU/MEMORY_MB/DISK_GB, sometimes VGPU, sometimes PCPU), then save the compute node rather than rely on the _resource_change method. However, I think there are at least two issues with doing that:

1. This code is removed from _update_to_placement how where we get the provider tree with updating inventory, so we'd have to shuffle where the compute node save happens which is likely gross(ish).

2. The bigger issue is doing that assumes nothing else in the ComputeNode fields matters besides the stuff reported in the provider tree, and that's not going to be true since the compute node has fields like current_workload, running_vms, disk_available_least, metrics, stats, etc - all crap that gets populated during this resource tracking audit and reported to the scheduler (and it's filters/weighers, which might be out of tree) via the ComputeNode record.

So I think we're safe to just remove this NOTE since it's bogus like I suspected.
Done - instead of just removing this I'll also replace it with a comment explaining why we need to do this regardless of the provider tree stuff so someone isn't confused in the future.
I think that comment might be bogus but I'll have to dig into the context of it. It's not the first time I've seen it and it's puzzled me.
Thanks for digging into that Matt. I agree with your reasoning.

releasenotes/notes/resize-auto-revert-6e.message:
This is an API behavior change right?

Consider the cloud has resize_confirm_window=1 and my script's logic is that I wait for the instance to enter ACTIVE or ERROR state. On ACTIVE, I assume things worked, and on ERROR I wake up a human. Now, I'll never (reliably) get ERROR state in my polling and all the humans will remain asleep. I have to change my script to poll for whether or not the flavor looks different now instead of an indication that the thing failed.

My argument would be to not auto-revert, independent of the behavior change decision. If we're going to do it, it seems like it's reasonably surprising to people.

I agree that a 500 would be fixed without a microversion, but not in a way that makes some other big change, but in just putting the instance into ERROR state or something like that.

It's a behaviour change, sure, which is why I called it out in a release note. Whether it's a change in the defined API is arguable, though. In general, things which result in errors other than parameter or state validation type errors are a grey area for the API, and we do change that from time to time without adding microversions. If this error was synchronous it would be a 5XX error, and in general we fix those.

I agree it's at least arguable, though. If we thought that the error behaviour was sufficiently well defined in the API to be maintained, and that in practice somebody might be relying on it, we'd need to add a microversion to resize. We'd also have to bump some RPC calls as it would have to propagate api->conductor->compute. It would also make this impossible to backport.

If the consensus is that this really is an API change I'll add the above, but personally I'm not convinced it's worth it.

I looked at this old review today because it came up during an internal call, and on the surface, it reminded me of different review we recently merged around cold migrate to self failing [before it starts] and setting the server state to ACTIVE/STOPPED instead of ERROR:

https://review.opendev.org/633227

After reading the comments on this old review, I wondered if the recently merged change was in the same vein. We discussed it in IRC:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2019-06-26.log.html#t2019-06-26T16:17:02

and the conclusion was that the recently merged change does not break automated script's ability to carry out a cold migrate wrt server state observation. Whereas this old review would have, because it would have auto-reverted a server that already went through the RESIZING state and so a transition like: ACTIVE -> RESIZING -> ACTIVE would no longer be distinguishable as success/failure to migrate/resize.

In discussing trying to recover from a failure in finish_resize today with melwitt [1] I suggested one option, which is part of this patch but I wouldn't do the auto-rollback thing, is allow revert_resize in the API to work on instances in ERROR status but only if we can detect in the API that the instance was undergoing a resize when it failed, i.e. the old_vm_state/old_flavor/new_flavor/migration_context etc are on the instance still. It wouldn't be automatic. The admin/user would have to do it manually. It might not work, I don't trust that the revert flow is totally idempotent depending on how finish_resize fails (setting up networks/volumes back to the source could be janky, you'd have to test it). Anyway, it's an idea. It would likely be a microversion as well since it's a change in API behavior (though maybe that's debatable if it's a bug fix of sorts).

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2019-11-13.log.html#t2019-11-13T21:49:12

nova/tests/unit/utils.py.message:
I considered testing the len(), but that will spuriously succeed with e.g. [1, 1, 2] == [1, 2, 2].

I could avoid the problem by enforcing that `iterable` and `other` be actual lists, and sorting them to compare them. But this is way simpler, and yagni.

I think a collections.Counter (a.k.a a bag) can solve it.

    assert collections.Counter([]) != collections.Counter([1])
    assert collections.Counter({}) != collections.Counter((1,))
    assert collections.Counter({}) != collections.Counter({1})

    assert collections.Counter([1]) == collections.Counter({1})
    assert collections.Counter([1, 2, 3]) == collections.Counter([3, 2, 1])
    assert collections.Counter([3, 2, 1]) == collections.Counter(range(1, 4))

    assert collections.Counter([1, 1, 2]) != collections.Counter([1, 2, 2])
    assert (collections.Counter([1, 2, 2, 3])
            != collections.Counter(range(1, 4)))

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/backu.message: The registries information should be added under section "docker_registries:"
this is failing tox lint, I have no idea why.

Looks like check for the "defaults" is removed. If insecure_registry is found ("defaults" registry is used during bootstrap), we still need to set the key "defaults:" under section "docker_registries:" instead of set individual registry since the key "defaults" in overrides file is used to determine if a config update needs to be done for docker or not during bootstrap or restore. Since “defaults” defines common values, we need to pick up the common values for each registry and put it under “defaults:”, the rest different values will be added under each registry.
Seems like you forget to convert it back.
I think you can combine these and remove the set_fact above, only need to write is_secure_registry: False if insecure.stdout|bool is true.

Also, I see that we can remove registries from service-parameter although insecure_registry is True, this will most likely break the deployment and we won't me able to extract the correct defaults when backing up.

The nail here is insecure_registry, what is the purpose of it? From my pov it should be refactored and added to each repository section in docker_registries:, not globally (which is not global anyway as it seems to only impact one of the 5 regiestries!).
Doing this change will make "defaults:" section only relevant in the initial bootstrap context, it will no longer matter at B&R as each configured registry will be completely defined in service-parameter-list.
We may have the case that the private registry is not authenticated. In this case, the registry will not have username, password and type. It will fail.

When defaults: is used I see that all registries are getting authenticated even if not defined in localhost.yml therefore there is no case of private registry not getting authenticated.

E.g. from localhost.yml:

 ssl_ca_cert: /home/sysadmin/domain.crt
docker_registries:
  docker.io:
    url: 10.10.1.50:6001
  k8s.gcr.io:
    url: 10.10.1.50:6001
  gcr.io:
    url: 10.10.1.50:6001
  quay.io:
    url: 10.10.1.50:6001
  defaults:
    type: docker
    username: reguser
    password: regpassword
is_secure_registry: False

Note that docker.elastic.co is missing.

Then, alhough not configured in localhost.yml, in system service-parameters we find docker.elastic.co configured with authentication:

 [sysadmin@controller-0 ~(keystone_admin)]$  system service-parameter-list | grep elastic-registry
| b9e1a8a3-af18-46cd-9eae-43babf0caeda | docker   | elastic-registry | auth-secret                 | 0376bc1e-99b4-4e87-8c6c-78a5aa090d62 | None        | None     |
| c2f88695-22f9-4581-85f4-4334a4467135 | docker   | elastic-registry | type                        | docker                               | None        | None     |
| a9d8b7b7-ab69-4028-8172-706df71eecce | docker   | elastic-registry | url                         | docker.elastic.co                    | None        | None     |

At backup it results in this output:

docker_registries:
  defaults: {password: regpassword, type: docker, username: reguser}
  docker.elastic.co: {url: docker.elastic.co}
  docker.io: {url: '10.10.1.50:6001'}
  gcr.io: {url: '10.10.1.50:6001'}
  k8s.gcr.io: {url: '10.10.1.50:6001'}
  quay.io: {url: '10.10.1.50:6001'}

Which include docker.elastic.co and is correct.


As a sidenote, problem here is that default forces user to set 'url:' for all registries. Yet is_secure_registry will skip security only for docker.elastic.co. Why are we doing it like this?
Then is_secure_registry converts into the negated values when it gets stored into sysinv as insecure_registry. Counterintuitive.

Can you verify if the right format of registries info will be written?

ie..
docker_registries:
  k8s.gcr.io:
    url: xxx
  gcr.io:
    url: xxx
  ...

kuryr_kubernetes/controller/drivers/netw.message: it is different that a policy is egress only or that there is no ingress matches right? I think _parse_rules does not account for policyType, so not sure this covers all the cases

As we don't care about egress, we should only update the LBaaS SG (the return of selectors will trigger that) in case an ingress match has occurred, regardless of egress match.
So, in case of egress only, for sure the SG will not get update as we're only checking ingress.
should this 'if' be out of the for loop?

I don't see a reason why. These conditions are in place to avoid the creation of the Egress rule for the current SVC. First it checks if the matched allowed resource by the Policy is a Pod and if it's selected by the SVC. Or if it's a namespace and matches the SVC namespace.
Do you see any other case that might not be covered?
what is this matched used for? is this meant to be indent inside the for loop of 611 and be if matched then break?
right... I was not thinking about ipblock here, and due to indentation I didn't see that it is actually skipping lines 623-629 if there is no match

In case a 'cidr' is defined at the resource object this means an IPBlock rule is specified at the Network Policy. So, if the Service has the same namespace as the Policy and some backend pod of the SVC is in the IPBlock range a SG rule to that SVC should be created. Otherwise the SG rule creation should be skipped.

Perhaps I can extract that code fragment(line 604-616) to another function and return as soon as a pod matches an IPBlock.
